column3: Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4657_ee3274f94d94833efe364346d2c74d8be6a18a83/ for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-te
I'd recommend using uint16 for the port instead of int32.  You can use 0 for "invalid".  A port has always been uint16, and making it int32 just seems odd.\n
How is the process side of this moving forward? I know it has been discussed on the mailing list on some point,  but I think it still needs e.g. a BIP number.\n
Closing for now, as no active development is happening on this.\n
Can you at least try to respect the coding style rules we have (include ordering etc.)?\n
This collides with NODE_GETUTXO in #4351 / BIP 64\n

If this continues to produce hectoring, then the most appropriate action is to remove that rule from doc/coding.md.  At some point you need to ask yourself whether this is satisfying your personal OCD versus making the bitcoin project and its developers more (or less!) productive.\n

@Diapolo is quite right to point this out if it goes against coding standards and @jgarzik is quite right to point out that the coding standards may need revising.\n\nMay I take this moment to suggest reading the "four agreements"? (http://crossfitcetro.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/the_four_agreements.jpg) - I'm seeing all too often people taking things a bit too personally on here, however, it

It makes sense to have a well-defined coarse include order. I.e. first your own include, then dependencies within the project, then dependencies outside the project. This makes sure that the compiler checks that your own include file (in this case extservices.h) includes everything it needs on its own.\n\nAs for alphabetical sorting, it could be argued that that is a step too far, although if you
